title: Jenna Kaye-Kauderer, Scott Steinberg
description: They are to hike with their families through Medicine Bow–Routt National Forests in Colorado to find a spot for the ceremony.
content: Jenna Blair Kaye-Kauderer and Scott Michael Steinberg are to be married March 29 in Medicine Bow-Routt National Forests in Steamboat Springs, Colo. Halley Kaye-Kauderer, the bride’s sister, who is affiliated with Open Ministry, is to officiate. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Champagne Powder Room, an events space at the top of the mountain, before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Coronavirus Lockdown Leaves Vast Numbers Stranded and Hungry
description: The sudden shutdown of businesses has upended the lives of millions of migrant laborers in Indian cities. More than a dozen migrants have died, and anger is rising.
content: NEW DELHI — In one of the biggest migrations in India’s modern history, hundreds of thousands of migrant laborers have begun long journeys on foot to get home, having been rendered homeless and jobless by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Cuomo: ‘Thousands Will Pass Away’
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that 237 people had died since the day before, the largest one-day increase in the state since the coronavirus outbreak began.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that 237 people had died since the day before, the largest one-day increase in the state since the coronavirus outbreak began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: The Psychological Trauma That Awaits Our Doctors and Nurses
description: Don’t underestimate the moral anguish of deciding who gets a ventilator.
content: This is the moment to pray for the psychological welfare of our health care professionals. In the months ahead, many will witness unimaginable scenes of suffering and death, modern Pietàs without Marys, in which victims are escorted into hospitals by their loved ones and left to die alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Giovannini
title: Michael Sorkin, 71, Dies; Saw Architecture as a Vehicle for Change
description: Mr. Sorkin, who died of the coronavirus, promoted social justice in his prodigious output of essays, lectures and designs.
content: Michael Sorkin, one of architecture’s most outspoken public intellectuals, a polymath whose prodigious output of essays, lectures and designs, all promoting social justice, established him as the political conscience in the field, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: How Russia’s Troll Farm Is Changing Tactics Before the Fall Election
description: The Kremlin-backed Internet Research Agency, which interfered in the 2016 election, is using different methods to hide itself better.
content: Ahead of November’s election, American intelligence officials and others are on high alert for mischief from Russia’s Internet Research Agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Now Playing Nightly on Instagram: Sketch Comedy’s Newest Star
description: Names big and small are pivoting to online humor, but the standouts are the character-driven performers who were there all along, especially Meg Stalter.
content: Everyone in comedy is now either an internet star or an aspiring one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Health Crisis, as Seen From Inside a Prison
description: An inmate talks about the AIDS experience, and a leader in prison education stresses the value of in-person teaching.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines to April 30 as U.S. Cases Top 140,000
description: The global count has passed 700,000, an official warns Britain that some kind of lockdown may last for months and Joe Biden urges mail-in elections.
content: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauna Farnell
title: How Skiing Through a Pandemic Can Create a Community Crisis
description: North American ski resorts have closed in response to the coronavirus, but mountain sports have still drawn crowds, alarming public safety officials.
content: As winter sports resorts in North America closed in response to the coronavirus outbreak, skiers and snowboarders began flocking to backcountry trails or to slopes where they could trek uphill and then take a downhill run. Though the activities are not forbidden, public officials have begun imploring the skiers and snowboarders to scale back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: 8 Killed After Philippine Plane Bursts Into Flames
description: All on board, including a doctor, a nurse and foreign nationals, were killed after the plane, used in the country’s coronavirus response, caught fire as it took off in Manila for Japan.
content: MANILA — A plane used as an air ambulance by the Philippine health department to fight the coronavirus outbreak burst into flames as it took off from Manila’s airport for Japan on Sunday night, killing all onboard, the airport said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman
title: Is the U.S. Headed Toward a Short British-Style Election?
description: Party conventions are in jeopardy, campaigning is on hold and local candidates are playing the role of good Samaritan instead of traditional politician.
content: From the White House to the county courthouse, the coronavirus pandemic has drastically upended the 2020 elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Crisis in The Sahel Becoming France’s Forever War
description: Riding along with French troops hunting Islamist militants in France’s unwinnable West African war.
content: AWAGATE FOREST, MALI — For two days, dozens of armored vehicles carrying 180 elite soldiers with the French Foreign Legion lumbered over West Africa’s scrubby savanna to reach a suspected hide-out for Islamist militants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish, Sarah Kliff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: The U.S. Tried to Build a New Fleet of Ventilators. The Mission Failed.
description: As the coronavirus spreads, the collapse of the project helps explain America’s acute shortage.
content: Thirteen years ago, a group of U.S. public health officials came up with a plan to address what they regarded as one of the medical system’s crucial vulnerabilities: a shortage of ventilators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China Created a Fail-Safe System to Track Contagions. It Failed.
description: After SARS, Chinese health officials built an infectious disease reporting system to evade political meddling. But when the coronavirus emerged, so did fears of upsetting Beijing.
content: The alarm system was ready. Scarred by the SARS epidemic that erupted in 2002, China had created an infectious disease reporting system that officials said was world-class: fast, thorough and, just as important, immune from meddling.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Driving the Long Haul, and Sensing a Slowdown
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2020.
content: “I live in something smaller than a jail cell all the time. I hear other people complaining and I’m like, get over it. There’s a lot of us living like this all the time, coronavirus or not.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: James L. Dolan, the Knicks Owner, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
description: Dolan is the first N.B.A. owner to publicly confirm
content: James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks, has tested positive for the coronavirus, the team announced Saturday night in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: Community Radio Fights to Stay Live (and Weird) Despite Coronavirus
description: Local stations have cut down on D.J.s coming to the studio, but playlists and personalities are holding strong as small stations get a chance to build bigger audiences.
content: “Greetings, virus people!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Asked Black Artists About Inspiration. Here, They Share Their Own.
description: Staff members from across The New York Times on 21st-century African-American artistry.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: Community Radio Fights to Stay Live (and Weird) Despite Coronavirus
description: Local stations have cut down on D.J.s coming to the studio, but playlists and personalities are holding strong as small stations get a chance to build bigger audiences.
content: “Greetings, virus people!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Leonard
title: The Coronavirus Is Upending Life in Rural America, Too
description: People here are stocking up on groceries and toilet paper — and guns and ammo and, soon, morel mushrooms.
content: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — How are things in my state during the pandemic? In a nearby town, about 20 miles away, people are caught up in it like many Americans. There’s been a run on canned goods, frozen pizzas and, of course, toilet paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Oil Prices Crash, Virus Hits, Commerce Stops: Iraq Is in Trouble.
description: Iraq depends on oil revenues, which have plummeted. The country is so desperate it is asking for donations to help it weather the pandemic.
content: BAGHDAD — When Iraq recorded its first cases of coronavirus, its health minister asked the government for $5 million in emergency funds. But there were no funds to be had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Coronavirus Taunts Evoke a Painful History for Asian-American Leaders
description: As Asian-Americans face xenophobia and President Trump has tied the virus to China, community and political leaders have tried to comfort constituents. But even they admit to feeling unnerved.
content: Soon after President Trump first uttered the phrase “Chinese virus,” Representative Grace Meng got a call from her parents, who had read about it in the newspaper. Had Mr. Trump, they wondered, really given the coronavirus that corrosive moniker?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Vanessa Swales
title: A City Hunkered Down to Survive an Outbreak. That Helped in a Tornado, Too.
description: Jonesboro, Ark., came through a devastating tornado without any deaths, partly because businesses were closed and people were sheltered at home from the coronavirus.
content: ATLANTA — Some in Jonesboro, Ark., saw a miracle on Saturday after a tornado roared through town. It tore through businesses already closed by the coronavirus and  neighborhoods where people had already been told to social distance by hunkering down at home. Not a soul died.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Driving the Long Haul, and Sensing a Slowdown
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2020.
content: “I live in something smaller than a jail cell all the time. I hear other people complaining and I’m like, get over it. There’s a lot of us living like this all the time, coronavirus or not.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Dwyer
title: What Sept. 11 Taught Us About Confronting Catastrophe
description: Unused emergency gurneys, a defining image from 9/11, have much to tell us today, when there isn’t a bed to spare. A veteran E.R. nurse explains.
content: From careful planning and much drilling, medical workers knew without being told that they should roll a fleet of gurneys and wheelchairs onto the sidewalk outside St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, New York’s last mortal catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Liberty University Brings Back Its Students, and Coronavirus Fears, Too
description: The decision by the school’s president, Jerry Falwell Jr., to partly reopen his evangelical university enraged residents of Lynchburg, Va. Then students started getting sick.
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. — As Liberty University’s spring break was drawing to a close this month, Jerry Falwell Jr., its president, spoke with the physician who runs Liberty’s student health service about the rampaging coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Margaret Walker, Aran Clair
description: The couple met at Princeton, from which they graduated.
content: Margaret Frances Matilda Walker and Aran Lundgren Clair were married March 25 on the plaza of the Arlington Courthouse in Arlington, Va. Isabel Kaldenbach, a civil celebrant authorized by the Arlington County Circuit Court, officiated. The couple originally planned to marry at the First Presbyterian Church in Nashville before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracy Meng, Kyle Matson
description: The couple attended the same church and worked for the same San Francisco company, but they were brought together by the dating app Hinge.
content: Tracy Lingchen Meng and Kyle Andrew Matson were married March 28 at their home in San Francisco. James W. Carson, a friend of the couple who was deputized as a temporary officiant by Marin County, Calif., officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Saw Another Woman on the Platform Do an Obvious Double Take’
description: Seeing a familiar face while waiting for the No. 6, a snack on the go and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: What I Learned When My Husband Got Coronavirus
description: An editor at The Times shares an intimate essay about her family’s fight against the pandemic.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Pasta with white sausage sauce, a spicy white bean stew, kimchi soup are just a few of the very good things you can make this week.
content: Good morning. My friend David Carr, who died in 2015, had a line about newspapering that’s true of cooking as well. David, one of the great journalists of his generation and a voice in The Times I miss every day, would deploy it as a plain statement of fact, nothing to be ashamed of, generally after a long day of work that didn’t amount to much on the page. Big sigh, then: “Sometimes it’s not very good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Bail Out Journalists. Let Newspaper Chains Die.
description: The coronavirus is likely to hasten the end of advertising-driven media, our columnist writes. And government should not rescue it.
content: Elizabeth Green was musing the other day about buying 261 newspapers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grandchildren: ‘Our Joy and Our Job’
description: A grandmother suggests ways of helping children and families in this difficult time. Also: The lack of diversity at Stuyvesant High School in New York.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, India’s Lockdown, North Korea: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Solnit
title: Who Will Win the Fight for a Post-Coronavirus America?
description: Every disaster shakes loose the old order. What replaces it is up to us.
content: The scramble has already begun. The possibilities for change, for the better or the worse, for a more egalitarian or more authoritarian society, burst out of the gate like racehorses at times like these.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Young
title: Nothing Matters Anymore (Except What Actually Does)
description: There’s so much I did two months ago that seems ludicrous now.
content: I was committed to dying without ever learning the Electric Slide. You know how everyone has a thing, one of those random eccentricities people associate with you? I was the “guy who always sits during the Electric Slide.” Do you realize how resolute you must be, as a 41-year-old black American man, to attend decades worth of cookouts, birthday parties, game nights, family reunions and wedding receptions and not allow yourself to learn the World’s Mildest Line Dance?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Looking for Uplifting Stories in a Dark Time
description: We ask readers for examples of how the pandemic has brought out the best in humanity.
content: The world is facing a crisis as the coronavirus spreads. But sometimes challenges bring out the best in people. There are stories of citizens going out of their way to help one another as well as supporting local businesses, crafting masks, setting up food banks, etc. We’d like to hear about your uplifting experiences in the midst of this tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: A Fight Over Money, Loyalty and Who Gets Credit for an Artist’s Rise
description: Derek Fordjour and the gallery that once worked with him are battling in court over pieces he promised to create before his career took off.
content: Six years ago, when Derek Fordjour was a little-known art student at Hunter College, before Michael Ovitz and Beyoncé began collecting his work, before his paintings came to sell for more than $100,000, the fledgling artist struck a deal with a New York gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Bail Out Journalists. Let Newspaper Chains Die.
description: The coronavirus is likely to hasten the end of advertising-driven media, our columnist writes. And government should not rescue it.
content: Elizabeth Green was musing the other day about buying 261 newspapers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines Through End of April
description: The president, facing grim figures from his health advisers, starkly reversed an earlier upbeat assessment that the country could relax the guidelines by Easter.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump retreated Sunday from his desire to relax coronavirus guidelines by Easter, announcing instead that all Americans must continue to avoid nonessential travel, going to work, eating at bars and restaurants, or gathering in groups of more than 10 for at least another month and perhaps until June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: How Much Should the Public Know About Who Has the Coronavirus?
description: Amid calls for more transparency, a debate is raging among public health experts over how much data on the spread of the virus should be released.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When the first case of the coronavirus in Silicon Valley was discovered in late January, health officials were faced with a barrage of questions: What city did the patient live in? Whom had he come in contact with? Which health clinic had he visited before he knew he was infected?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Said He Was the President of Manufacturing. Then Disaster Struck.
description: For a leader who has embraced the language of a wartime president, it is as if the Pentagon asked for missiles and bombers but wouldn’t say how many or where they should be delivered.
content: When President Trump came to office, he promised a new day with America’s manufacturers, casting himself as the first president who understood their needs. He toured factory floors, often handing out his signature “Make America Great Again” hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Hafner
title: ‘A Heart-Wrenching Thing’: Hospital Bans on Visits Devastate Families
description: To curb the risk of spreading the coronavirus, hospitals nationwide are banning visits from family and friends.
content: The last time Peter John Dario saw his father alive was on March 14, at the entrance to a hospital in Edison, N.J. An employee took him away in a wheelchair, telling Mr. Dario and his mother gently but unequivocally that they could not go in the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Throwing Money at a Pandemic
description: As unemployment numbers broke a grim record, Congress rushed to pass a $2 trillion rescue bill.
content: There’s no way to sugarcoat the devastating numbers that came out this past week. As the United States surpassed China in the number of confirmed coronavirus cases, record-high jobless numbers brought the economic toll of the pandemic into sharp focus. Congress rushed to push through a rescue bill. But will it be enough?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Portrait of a Lady on Fire’ and ‘Beef House’
description: Watch a tender romance on Hulu, or try out a new sitcom from Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim.
content: PORTRAIT OF A LADY ON FIRE (2019) Stream on Hulu. Much of this moving love story from the filmmaker Céline Sciamma is told through intense gazes and delicate gestures. Marianne (Noémie Merlant), an artist in 18th-century France, is commissioned to paint a portrait of Héloïse (Adèle Haenel), a lonely noblewoman who is soon to be married off. The portrait is a gift for Héloïse’s future husband, but she is dreading the wedding and refuses to sit for the painting. So her mother hires Marianne as a companion and asks her to create the artwork in secret after observing Héloïse’s every move. Her looks don’t go unnoticed. The more time Héloïse and Marianne spend alone, the deeper they fall into a passionate affair. The main draw here is the romance, but the movie is also a tale of sisterhood: an examination of women breaking free from the shackles of tradition, class and patriarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 29, 2020.
content: A picture caption with an article on Page 32 about the Stellenbosch Triennale misidentified a member of the Asafo Black collective from Ghana. He is Jeffrey Otoo, not Daniel Mensah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches Two Short-Range Ballistic Missiles
description: The country has carried out a handful of similar tests this month. The missiles fell into waters between the North and Japan.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Sunday, a week after its leader received a letter from President Trump offering to help the country fight the coronavirus, the South Korean military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus, New York, Sabrina Ionescu: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: Mike Longo, Jazz Pianist, Composer and Educator, Dies at 83
description: Best known for his long association with Dizzy Gillespie, Mr. Longo, who died of the coronavirus, also led a big band and promoted the work of other musicians.
content: Mike Longo, a jazz pianist, composer and educator best known for his long association with the trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, died on March 22 in Manhattan. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Egypt’s Female Lion Tamers Show the Men How to Do It
description: The broader struggle for women’s equality may be lagging in Egypt, but six women dominate the field of lion taming in the country.
content: GAMASA, Egypt — At her apartment in a seaside town, Luba el-Helw, a working Egyptian mother, faced multiple demands. She juggled business calls, prepared a chicken dish and parried the demands of her three sons, aged 4 to 8, who were stretched out before the TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal Naito, M.D
title: Gargling for Coronavirus? What Science Can Tell Us
description: There no firm proof that gargling prevents respiratory infections caused by coronavirus — or any virus or bacteria. But there’s also little downside.
content: As Americans search for ways to fight the spread of the coronavirus, one popular topic that has generated interest on the internet is gargling. What’s behind the gargling claim, and is there any medical proof that gargling may help to fight coronavirus or other respiratory infections?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Sheera Frenkel and Nicole Perlroth
title: Facebook, Google and Twitter Struggle to Handle November’s Election
description: After spending billions to avoid a repeat of 2016, the tech giants are careening from crisis to crisis as their foes change tactics.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The day after the New Hampshire primary last month, Facebook’s security team removed a network of fake accounts that originated in Iran, which had posted divisive partisan messages about the U.S. election inside private Facebook groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: What Social Distancing Looked Like in 1666
description: Humanity has been surviving plagues for thousands of years, and we have managed to learn a lot along the way.
content: A lot of English people believed 1666 would be the year of the apocalypse. You can’t really blame them. In late spring 1665, bubonic plague began to eat away at London’s population. By fall, roughly 7,000 people were dying every week in the city. The plague lasted through most of 1666, ultimately killing about 100,000 people in London alone — and possibly as many as three-quarters of a million in England as a whole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Lewis
title: Krzysztof Penderecki, Polish Composer With Cinematic Flair, Dies at 86
description: Mr. Penderecki’s modernist compositions turned up in films like “The Exorcist” and influenced a generation of edgy rock musicians.
content: Krzysztof Penderecki, a Polish composer and conductor whose modernist works jumped from the concert hall to popular culture, turning up in soundtracks for films like “The Exorcist” and “The Shining” and influencing a generation of edgy rock musicians, died on Sunday at his home in Krakow. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Trump Is Hurting His Own Re-election Chances
description: Don’t be fooled by snapshot polls.
content: The strangest part of President Trump’s coronavirus response is that it’s almost certainly damaging his chances of re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Politics of a Pandemic
description: Trump wants us to see him as defeating a foreign enemy.
content: The coronavirus pandemic is first and foremost a global public health crisis. But here in the United States — as is likely true in other countries — the response to it is heavily overlaid with political calculations. It is both obvious and inevitable. The crisis is unfolding in the lead-up to the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: They Create Nightmare Worlds for TV. Now They’re Living in One.
description: Amid the pandemic, the producers of dystopian dramas like “The Handmaid’s Tale” and “Westworld” see their work in a different light.
content: They tried to warn us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: White House Airlifts Medical Supplies From China in Coronavirus Fight
description: Officials have teamed up with medical supply companies to speed the arrival of masks, gloves, gowns and other goods.
content: WASHINGTON — A commercial aircraft carrying 80 tons of gloves, masks, gowns and other medical supplies from Shanghai touched down in New York on Sunday, the first of 22 scheduled flights that White House officials say will funnel much-needed goods to the United States by early April as it battles the world’s largest coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York State Exceeds 1,000 Coronavirus Deaths
description: “Thousands of people will pass away,” Gov. Andrew Cuomo warned as Mayor Bill de Blasio said New York City had a week’s worth of medical supplies.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday offered a grim assessment of the coronavirus pandemic engulfing the state, as he reported that 237 people had died since the day before,  the largest one-day increase since the coronavirus outbreak began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Teachers’ Herculean Task: Moving 1.1 Million Children to Online School
description: New York City’s 75,000 public school educators are facing a challenge unlike anything in their careers. For students to avoid permanent setbacks, the success of remote learning is critical.
content: In the days before remote instruction began, Chauntae Brown, a second-grade teacher at P.S. 80 in Jamaica, Queens, scrambled to teach parents without Wi-Fi how to use cellphone hot spots. She rummaged in her garage to find materials — a world map, a “Welcome” sign, an apple-shaped chalkboard — to transform her living room wall into a classroom. She grabbed a plastic tiara because, she said, “I’m the queen of this castle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Coronavirus Slowdown in Seattle Suggests Restrictions Are Working
description: Officials in Washington State worry that their gains are precarious, but they see evidence that containment strategies have lowered the rate of virus transmission.
content: SEATTLE — The Seattle area, home of the first known coronavirus case in the United States and the place where the virus claimed 37 of its first 50 victims, is now seeing evidence that strict containment strategies, imposed in the earliest days of the outbreak, are beginning to pay off — at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Rich Europeans Flee Virus for 2nd Homes, Spreading Fear and Fury
description: In France and the rest of Europe, the affluent decamp cities to spend their confinement in vacation homes, widening class divides.
content: ÎLE DE NOIRMOUTIER, France — On their peaceful island off France’s Atlantic Coast, some of the locals watched, with growing dread and rage, the images from Paris. As rumors began circulating about an imminent nationwide lockdown to stem the coronavirus outbreak, hordes of Parisians jammed into trains, an odd surfboard sometimes sticking out of the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times
